A quick note: originally, I wrote that Peter said that the US bombed Japan until they surrendered. However, one reader informed me that Japan actually made moves to surrender before the US bombed them, but that the US bombed them anyway, potentially just to test out their bombs and show their power. That being said, another reader informed me that unconditional surrender seemed unlikely on Japan's part, especially since Japan didn't make an offer to surrender after the first bomb. The various sources I've looked at tend to contradict each other, but just keep in mind that history is far more complicated than it's portrayed in the history books—the bombing of Japan is clearly far less black and white than we think it is. It's realistic for Peter not to know any of this, given what we get in history classes here in the US, but I reworded that line so as not to spread misinformation either way.

Peter flopped from his desk chair onto the floor, burying his face in a dirty shirt before realizing how disgusting it smelled and rolling away from it.
“You appear to be in mild distress, Mr. Parker. Should I call Mr. Stark?”
Peter flailed. “No! No, I’m fine. Thanks though, JARVIS.”
“Is it accurate to presume that the primary stressor is your history test tomorrow?”
Peter lifted his head and looked suspiciously at the ceiling. “How did you know?”
“Contrived from your emotional state, I have calculated that the chance of your test being tomorrow is high, and that it is exceptionally likely your test is for your history class, based on the available content.”
“... Available content?”
“The papers on your desk cover material on the second World War, Mr. Parker.”
Peter sighed. “I’m screwed. I can’t remember any of the dates or the names of the battles or the leaders and there’s too many countries… I should’ve paid attention in class, but I was tired… I didn’t get enough sleep. What even is sleep? I should be fine. I just have to remember stuff. Why are there so many countries in the war?”
“It is a World War, sir.”














Peter buried his face in his arms. “Urgh.”
“Peter?”
Peter sat bolt upright to find Steve in his doorway. “H- Wh- What’re you doing here?”
“JARVIS said you needed help,” Steve said, looking a mix of worried and bemused. “Are you okay? Why are you on the floor?”
“Are you kidding me? Not cool, JARVIS! I’m fine!” Peter crossed his arms indignantly.
“There is a high probability that my actions will lead to an improved outcome, based on Mr. Rogers’s knowledge of World War II and your unwillingness to ask for help,” JARVIS told him. Peter watched as Steve ambled over to his desk, scanning through the papers. Peter’s eye twitched a little, and he glared at the ceiling.
“I can help with this stuff. What are you having trouble with?” Steve asked, stepping forward and offering Peter a hand. Peter chewed on his lip before ceding with an exhale and letting Steve help him up.
“I get the basics, I just can’t keep track of the dates. And who started what, where, and why.”
“Alright,” Steve said. “Is memorizing things usually difficult for you?”
“No!” said Peter, slightly frustrated. “It just won’t stick. I don’t know why.”
Steve put a hand to Peter’s forehead, and Peter jumped.
“What’re you doing?”
“Making sure you’re not sick,” Steve said lightly. “That can make memorization difficult.”
“I’m not sick.” Peter sounded a bit defensive. He stepped forward and started shuffling through his papers.
“Have you slept enough?”
“I’m fine, Steve. I just need to pass the damn test.” Peter rubbed his forehead. “Sorry, I’m sorry. That was rude.”
“Don’t worry about it.” Steve reached out and gripped his shoulder, steering him towards his bed. Peter didn’t register the fact that he’d moved until he found himself lying down; Steve was pulling blankets over him. 
“What- Steve, I have to study!” Peter tried to get up, only to be pushed back down by Steve. 
“To study, you need to be well-rested. Take a nap, eat dinner, then I’ll help you study.”
“But-”
“I’ll sit on you,” Steve threatened, looking half-serious. “Sleep, Peter.”
Peter yawned in spite of himself, then frowned. “That wouldn’t stop me, y’know.”
Steve raised his eyebrows. “I’m pretty heavy.”
“I lifted part of a building.”
Steve’s face went hard and soft at the same time. He didn’t reply, just tucked the blankets under Peter’s chin and straightened up, an unreadable expression on his face through Peter’s droopy eyes. He headed for the door, and Peter’s eyes fell shut. He was asleep before Steve had left the room.
----
“Peter. Wake up, kid.” Tony’s voice was uncharacteristically gentle as Peter blinked himself into a state of relative consciousness. 
“Huh?” He sat up, scrubbing at his eyes. “Wha’ time is it?”
“Six thirty. Time for dinner. You feeling alright?”
“Feeling- yeah! I feel fine.” Peter scrambled to his feet, nearly tripping over his blankets. He straightened his rumpled clothes and ran his fingers through his hair. “What’s for dinner?”
“Grilled cheese. The fancy kind that Barnes makes.”
“Mm. I’m starving.” Peter made for the door, but Tony grabbed the back of his shirt.
“You’re sure you’re okay?”
“I’m fine,” Peter said, slightly confused. “I’m not sick or anything, I was just a little tired.”
Tony released him. “Alright, kid. Let’s get you fed.”
They headed out to the elevator; almost everyone was already in the dining room when they arrived. 
“There’s the baby,” Clint said, messing with Peter’s hair as he sat down.
“I’m not a baby,” Peter grumbled, but it held no heat. He piled grilled cheese sandwiches onto his plate and dug in, his mouth bulging with huge bites. “God, theth are delithiouth.”
“Confirm,” said Natasha, and her eyes twinkled as Bucky glared at her.
“You’re the worst,” he muttered.
“Confirm,” Clint said. Bucky huffed and took a bite of his sandwich. 
“Thankth for the grilled cheethe,” said Peter, his mouth stuffed. A hint of amusement flashed across Bucky’s face.
“Don’t talk with your mouth full,” Pepper reprimanded. Peter ducked his head.
“Thorry.”
“You let me talk with my mouth full,” Clint said. “I’m offended on Peter’s behalf.”
“Thanks, Clint.” Peter grinned. Pepper rolled her eyes.
“Clint, I’d have send you to etiquette class years ago if I had any control over you.”
“You could blackmail him,” Tony said. “That might work.”
Pepper brightened. “Anybody know his deepest, darkest secrets? Natasha?”
“I know a few,” Natasha said. “The first being that he still has his-”
“Nat!” Clint squeaked. “You promised not to tell!”
“Will you go to etiquette class?”
“No!”
“He still had his te-”
“Fine!” Clint said, throwing his hands up. “Fine. I’ll go to etiquette class. But that was cruel.”
“Confirm,” Natasha said, throwing a glance at Bucky, who planted his face on the table with a thud.
“Stop teasing him,” Steve scolded. “If you tease him, he’ll never make any of you grilled cheese or cookies again.”
“Now that’s a threat. Wow,” Tony said. “All of you shut up.”










Bucky lifted his head and smirked faintly before taking another bite of sandwich. Peter finished his food in record time and reached for seconds, but none were left. Nobody seemed to have noticed his aborted movement, yet he found half a sandwich on his plate when he looked down after listening to Clint and Steve argue over country music. He scrunched his eyebrows, and he found Bucky watching him when he glanced back up. Bucky gestured for him to eat. Peter opened his mouth to argue, but Bucky fixed him with a terrifying glare and he quickly dropped his eyes, taking a bite of the half-sandwich. When he looked up a second time, Bucky was gone. Peter sat in confusion for a few moments before tuning in to the conversation, which consisted of Tony aggressively insisting that Clint’s taste in music was trash and should never be trusted. This lasted five minutes before Clint argued that at least his taste in clothing was better than Tony’s; Tony firmly disagreed. After five minutes of that, they moved on to teasing Steve about his old suit and how he looked like a floppy baby penguin, at which point Peter heard something drop onto his plate. He jumped, surprised to find two more grilled cheeses in front of him.


“Didn’t mean to scare you,” Bucky said almost inaudibly. “Careful. Those are hot.”




“Thanks,” Peter said. “Did you just make these? You really didn’t have to do that.”




Bucky shrugged. “Forgot you eat as much as Steve.”




“I mean, I don’t have to. I was mostly full. I’m sorry you had to do extra-”




“I like to cook,” Bucky grunted. “No hardship.”




“Thanks. Thank you.”




Bucky nodded. Peter wolfed down his new sandwiches, then took his plate to the kitchen. Steve followed.




“Feeling better?”




“Yeah,” Peter admitted. “Thanks.”




“You’ve got to take care of yourself, kid. Get enough sleep and all that.”




“I know.” Peter looked at the ground, shuffling his feet. Steve clapped a hand on his back.




“Ready to study?”




“Ready.”




----




“Can we start with dates?” Peter asked.




“Alright,” Steve said. “When did World War II begin?”




“1939. Um… September 1st?”




“Correct.”




“What was it like?” Peter asked, slightly hesitant.




“There was a whole lot of not knowing what would happen next. I don’t think anyone really expected it. I mean, there was the threat of war, but nobody thought ‘oh, this is the start of a world war.’ It was just gradual, until it wasn’t. People getting called to fight. War being the sole focus. Rations, fear, Pearl Harbor…” Steve shrugged. “Speaking of which, when was Pearl Harbor?”




“1941. December…” Peter chewed his lip. “December… Early December.”




“The seventh.”




“December seventh.”




Steve gave him a soft smile. “How about the Battle of Midway?”




“It was in 1942. In June, I think.”




“Right. Why was it important?”




“Most of the Japanese aircraft carriers got destroyed.”




Steve nodded. “And what do you know about the battle of Kursk?”




“It happened in 1943. It was an air strike? With the Russians against the Germans?”




“Almost. It was a tank battle, but there were forces in the air as well. It’s considered one of the greatest tank battles of the war.”




“Oh.”




“You were close,” Steve said. “Don’t be so hard on yourself. You’re doing well. What happened on June 6, 1944?”




Peter looked up. “D-day, right?”




“Right.”




“The Allies invaded France. They took back Paris a couple months later.”




“And what happened at the Battle of the Bulge?”




“The Germans staged an attack and lost.”




“Good. What army crossed the Rhine in 1945?”




“The US Third Army. Under General Patton.”




“And what happened next?”




“Hitler committed suicide. The Germans surrendered. The US bombed Japan. The war ended.”




“You got it.”




Peter nodded. “Can we review it one more time?”




“Sure. When did the war start?”


Peter didn’t mean to procrastinate, he really didn’t. They’d been given two weeks to read Fahrenheit 451, and he’d intended to get it done in the first week, but he kept pushing it back and pushing it back until it was the last night and they had an in-class essay to write on it the next morning. A plethora of choice words streamed through his head, and he chose three of the best to mutter under his breath. He was going to need coffee for this. He grabbed the book and hurried up to the kitchen, crossing his fingers that nobody was there at midnight. He was in luck. 
He tried to make coffee as quietly as possible, wishing he could web the coffee maker and dangle it out the window as it gurgled and poured. He mixed in an appropriate amount of sugar and cream, then sat down on a bar stool and began to read under the dim lights, coffee clutched tightly in hand. It lasted him through the first thirty pages, and he got up to make another. His eyes burned from exhaustion. He hadn’t gotten much sleep the night before, and had been planning on making it up. Plan foiled. 
He took a sip of the coffee and sat back down, gluing his eyes to the page and reading until he ran out of coffee again. He set his book down and just about jumped out of his skin when he saw Bucky watching him from the doorway. He clutched his chest, breathing hard. Bucky tilted his head.
“You didn’t notice me.”
“Obviously,” Peter squeaked.
“You’re usually more aware of your surroundings.”
“I was focused.”
“You’re exhausted. You should be in bed.”
“So should you,” Peter shot back, plopping his mug under the coffee maker.
Bucky shrugged. “I don’t have school tomorrow.”
“That’s the point,” Peter sighed. “I have to read this book for tomorrow. If I don’t read it, I’ll get a zero on the in-class essay.”
“You should’ve done it earlier,” Bucky said.
“I know,” Peter hissed. Then, more resigned, “I know.”
Bucky watched as Peter picked up his fresh coffee and took a long gulp, wincing at the sharp taste. He returned to his seat, resting his head on his arm for a moment before sitting up straight and picking up the book. Bucky made his way into the kitchen and began shuffling through the cupboards, pulling out ingredients and setting them on the counter. Peter turned around when he started cracking eggs.
“What’re you doing?”
“Making cookies.”
Peter raised his eyebrows. “Why?”
“So you can eat them.”
“Really?”
“No, I’m making cookies to throw out the window.”
Peter stared at him for a moment before huffing out a laugh. “I thought you were serious.”
“Get back to work. Maybe I am serious.”
Peter snapped back around in his seat and continued to read. God, he wanted cookies. His stomach rumbled. A small bowl of chocolate chips was placed in front of him, and he poured them into his mouth like he hadn’t eaten in a week. 
“Thanks,” he sighed.
“Focus,” Bucky replied. Peter took a sip of coffee and stared determinedly at page 63. He reread the first paragraph five times without absorbing any of it before dropping the book and rubbing aggressively at his eyes.
“My brain hurts.”
“Book boring?”
“I dunno. I’m too tired. Have you read it?”
Bucky shook his head. “It was past my time. Haven’t gotten around to it yet these days.”
“What’s your favorite book?” Peter asked.
“Haven’t decided. Read All My Sons by Arthur Miller earlier. Thought it was interesting.” Bucky squinted at him. “Get back to work. You procrastinate, you face the consequences.”
Peter exhaled. “I know.”
“You can do it,” Bucky said, suddenly softer. “Go on.”
Peter picked up the book and forced himself to read, guzzling his coffee like it was his lifeblood. When he ran out, Bucky snatched the mug away and placed it in the sink.
“That’s enough.”
“But-”
“Cookies in five minutes. You’ll live.”
Peter massaged his temples and looked back to the swimming words. He pushed through to page 85 before he heard to oven open and abandoned the book again.
“Keep reading,” Bucky said, and he groaned, reaching for the cookies. “They’re too hot.”
“I don’t care.”
“Wrong answer. Keep reading.”
Peter definitely didn’t whimper. He felt a hand ghost across his back and slouched forward, exhausted.
“Keep pushing,” Bucky said quietly. “Cookies in a minute.”
Peter propped himself up with his elbow and turned the page. “I should’ve just read the SparkNotes summary.”
“Building. Define spark-notes,” said Bucky.
“SparkNotes is a resource intended to assist readers with concise summaries of books. It is not a replacement for the text itself,” JARVIS said.
“That’s why I’m doing this,” Peter muttered. He let the book fall out of his hands when Bucky placed a plate of cookies in front of him. “Thank you.”


Bucky watched as Peter gobbled down cookie after cookie, only looking up after he’d eaten almost all of them.




“Crap. Did you want some?”




“Just one.”




Peter pushed the plate over, and Bucky took a cookie. Peter inhaled the last few and brought the plate to the sink, teetering a bit as he walked.




“Go lay down and read,” Bucky told him.




“I might fall asleep.”




“You won’t.”




----




Peter didn’t. Bucky was very talented at pinching toes. Every time Peter’s eyes fluttered, a decent amount of pressure was applied to his big toe, and he squeaked appropriately. Bucky seemed to be a toe-pinching veteran; Peter didn’t have the nerve to ask why. He was pretty sure that the vast majority of Bucky’s past was miserable. Regardless, he kept his focus well enough and only had twenty pages to go by two in the morning. His vision was blurry, and he had to squint to process the words in front of him. His eyelids drooped, and Bucky gave his toe a firm pinch from his seat at the end of the couch.




“Ow!”




“You’re almost done.”




Peter rubbed his eyes and forced them to focus. The last half of an hour felt like torture, and he threw the book on the floor when he finally finished. Bucky gave his toe a rewarding pat. Peter tried to get up, but his head spun and he sat back down with a thump. The couch was so comfy… he could sleep on it, right? He was ninety-nine percent sure that he was dreaming when he felt a metal arm under his knees and a flesh one under his back scooping him up, his head lolling to rest on a well-muscled shoulder as he was carried to the elevator.




----




Peter awoke blearily to his alarm less than four hours later. He squinted around, expecting to see the living room; he was surprised to find himself in his own bed, the covers wrapped warmly around him. He closed his eyes for just a moment before forcing himself out of bed, pulling on clean clothes and heading to the bathroom. He brushed his teeth, used the toilet, and splashed water on his face, wiping it off with a towel. He fixed his hair, cringing at the bags under his eyes upon studying himself in the mirror. Satisfied enough, he hurried up to grab breakfast before he had to leave for school. To his surprise, Bucky was standing in front of the stove, flipping pancakes. Nobody was usually up so early, except for Pepper, but she was always busy. 




“Mornin’,” Bucky grunted without turning around. “Your plate’s on the table.”




“Thanks,” Peter said, surprised. “You didn’t have to-”




“I told you last night, kid, I like to cook. Eat the damn food.”




Peter plopped down in his seat, shoveling the pancakes into his mouth, barely pausing to pour syrup on them. “Mmm.” 




Bucky set another plate down next to him as he gulped down his last bite.




“Are these for me?”




“No, they’re for building.”




“Sergeant Barnes is only joking, Mr. Parker,” JARVIS said. “Though I would delight in a stack of pancakes if I could eat them.”




“So they’re for me?”




“They’re for you.” Bucky rolled his eyes and simultaneously looked fond. It was an odd expression to see, especially on Bucky. Peter didn’t think too much on it though, instead deciding to inhale the second plate of pancakes. 




“Thank you,” he said when he finished. “I usually just have cereal.”




“You worked hard last night,” Bucky told him. “Hard work means reward. Keep that in mind today.”




Peter nodded, stacking his empty plates and placing them in the sink. He scooped up his bag and headed for the elevator.




“Thanks, Bucky. Seeya later.”




“Later,” Bucky said, inclining his head.




----




By lunchtime, Peter was definitely suffering. He was relieved to have gotten the essay out of the way; he did better than he thought he would, but he felt like he was going to fall asleep at any moment. His eyes were burning and his head felt heavy on his shoulders. He didn’t want to go to gym at all next block. Or see Flash. He ran his fingers through his hair, then forced himself to sit upright so he didn’t faceplant in his half-eaten nachos. 




“Peter?” 




“Huh?” Peter jerked his head up to find the principal’s secretary standing behind him.




“Peter didn’t do it,” Ned said. 




“Do what?” the secretary squinted at him, somewhat suspicious now.




“Whatever you’re about to give him detention for?” Ned sounded unsure.




“I’m not giving him detention,” the secretary huffed. “Though maybe I should give you one. Peter, someone’s here to take you to a doctor’s appointment. He said you forgot about it. He’s very menacing and I’d suggest that you get moving.”




“A doctor’s appointment?” Peter said dumbly.




“Yes,” the secretary replied, impatient. She flapped her hands, and Peter stood up, swaying a bit before he steadied himself and picked up his backpack. He tossed the remains of his lunch in the trash on his way out of the cafeteria, giving Ned and MJ a small wave. When he got the the main office, the last person he expected to see was standing by the door.




“Bucky? What-”




“We’re late,” Bucky said briskly. “C’mon.”




He steered Peter through the front doors and down the steps onto the sidewalk, slowing his pace as they retreated from the school.




“How come-”




“Hard work means reward. You read the book, you wrote the essay. Now you get to go home.”




“You- How- What? I don’t have a doctor’s appointment?”




“Why would you have a doctor’s appointment.”




“Oh,” Peter said weakly. “Yeah. Thanks.”




Bucky shrugged. “You just had gym and a study hall left. We have motivational Steve at home. No need for gym class version.”




Peter snorted. “Those videos are ridiculous.”




“They really play them in your school.”




“All the time,” Peter groaned. Bucky’s lips twitched. He watched as Peter yawned, almost tripping over a crack in the sidewalk. 




“You look terrible.”




“Thanks,” Peter said. “You kinda do too. How much sleep did you even get?”




“Two point three hours.”




“How? How are you functioning? I feel like death.”




“I’m used to functioning on little to no sleep.”




Peter tilted his head, studying Bucky, who shoved his hands deeper in his pockets.




“But you don’t seem dizzy or tired at all.”






“Used to it.”








“When was the last time you slept enough?” Peter asked, curious now.








“With or without sedatives.”








“Both?”








“Almost got cut in half last year. Required heavy sedatives to undergo medical treatment and recover. Without sedatives… a long time.” Bucky’s voice cracked slightly. Peter stared at him.








“That… That sucks, man. I’m sorry.”








“That’s life.”








Peter yawned again, scrunching up his face. He stumbled, and Bucky caught him by the handle on his backpack and pulled him back upright.








“Almost there,” Bucky said. Sure enough, the entrance to the tower was just a block away, and Peter wanted to collapse when they finally entered the lobby. He dragged himself into the elevator and leaned against the wall, closing his eyes as they shot upwards. When he opened them, Bucky was shepherding him out of the elevator and into his room. He dropped his backpack and flopped onto his bed; Bucky tucked the covers neatly beneath his chin and stepped back. 








“I’ll make you cookies when you wake up.”




“Peter,” Tony said, waiting until Peter had a mouthful of potatoes. “I got a call from your school today.”
Peter almost choked. Clint thumped his back sympathetically as he coughed. 
“What?” he wheezed, his eyes watering. “I haven’t gotten detention this month.”
“Good for you,” Steve said, smiling. Pepper frowned.
“No. Well, yes, but he shouldn’t ever be getting detention.”
“Your standards are too high,” said Clint. Pepper flicked his ear, and he yelped.
“Anyway,” Tony said. “They were wondering why we haven’t signed up for any parent-teacher conferences.”
“Conferences?” Natasha suddenly looked interested. “I’ll go.”
“I want to go!” Clint said.
“I’d like to go,” said Steve. 
“I’m going.” Tony crossed his arms. Peter hid behind his hands.
“Peter?” Steve prompted.
“I knew this would happen,” Peter mumbled.
“So you conveniently forgot to tell us?”
“No… Maybe.”
“Why?” Tony asked.
“I dunno.” Peter fixed his gaze firmly on his potatoes.
“You don’t want them to embarrass you,” Bucky said. Peter’s silence was his downfall.
“We’re not embarrassing!” Clint exclaimed. “We’re super cool!”
“I’d be embarrassed by Clint too,” Natasha said. “But he’s not going, so you don’t have to worry about that.”
“Hey! I’m totally-”
“You’re not going,” said Pepper. “Tony and Steve are going, because even though Natasha and Bucky would do a better job, Tony and Steve are insufferable idiots who can’t stand the thought of missing out on something fairly trivial in the scheme of things.”
“Conferences aren’t trivial!” Tony argued. “They’re very important. Peter agrees.”
“Don’t form Peter’s opinions for him,” Pepper scolded. “He’s at an impressionable age.”
“I’m not impressionable,” Peter said.
“Yes you are,” everyone chorused.
“Fine,” Peter sighed. “Just… don’t go all… y’know.”
“We’ll behave,” Steve promised. Tony held up his hands.
“Don’t put words in my mouth, Steve.”
“Yeah, he’s at an impressionable age,” Clint said. Tony sulked as everyone laughed at him.
“Whatever. I scheduled conferences with your chemistry teacher and your history teacher for tomorrow afternoon. You’d better patch up your selective memory, kid.”
“Sorry, Tony.”
Tony waved the apology away. “Tell us next time.”
“Alright.”

The next day, after chemistry class, Peter’s teacher pulled him aside. 
“I don’t appreciate you wasting my time with practical jokes, Mr. Parker.”
Peter stared at him, confused.
“I’m not going to sit in an empty classroom after school today and wait for Tony Stark and Steve Rogers to show up for a conference. I don’t fall for things like that.”
“It’s not a joke,” Peter said.
“Nice try, Mr. Parker. Don’t think I won’t be sending an email to your parents about this.”
Peter opened his mouth to argue, then closed it. There was no point. He shrugged, making for the door.
“There are better ways to get attention,” the teacher told him as he left. He gritted his teeth, shoving his hands in his pockets as he headed for his English class.

When he got back to the tower, he was surprised to find Natasha, Bucky, Pepper, and Clint waiting outside when he stepped out of the elevator into the hall. His eyebrows pinched together, and he blinked.
“Welcome home,” Clint said cheerfully, fluffing his hair.
“What are you guys doing here?” he asked.
“We’re having a party in your room.”
Peter was arrantly confused. “Why?”
“You’ll see,” Pepper said, her smile slightly impish. Peter rarely saw the look on her; she was usually the responsible one. It made him increasingly curious.
“C’mon,” said Natasha, waving everyone toward Peter’s room. Peter opened the door, letting everyone in. Clint flopped onto the bed, Pepper took the desk chair, and Natasha sat cross-legged on the carpet. Bucky scanned the room, then lowered himself into a bean bag in the corner. Peter plopped down on the fluffy carpet, tossing his backpack aside. 
“What are we doing?”
“Having a party!” Clint repeated.
“What kind of party?” asked Peter.
“A listening party,” Natasha said airily.
“So… music?”
“Nope!” Clint grinned. “Is it almost time?”
“Ten minutes,” Pepper said. 
“We could turn it on early,” said Natasha, glancing at Bucky, who nodded. He pulled out his phone, tapping at it until Steve’s voice filtered clearly into the room.
“... is ridiculous, we’ve passed these lockers already!”
“All the lockers look the same,” came Tony’s voice. “They’re probably different ones.”
“No, they’re the same! We must not have seen it. Let’s go back.”
“Let’s not.”
“We can ask the secretary for help,” Steve said.
